Thanks for this. It's interesting to that George Marsaglia's KISS RNG
is given the thumbs up, I used his XOR shift algorithm as the basis
for my FastRandom class in SharpNeat. I may well switch over to using
the KISS algorithm though based on the discussion in this article. Oh
and also someone made a comment on the codeproject page where
FastRandom lives - "Worst ever random generator!...Passes FIPS 140-1
with approximately 0.7 %. "

Not sure why this guy was so passionate about RNG's but I do intend to
check out this FIPS test one day.

Overall though I don't think NEAT is going to be particularly harmed
by the kind of flaws inherent in some of these RNGs. For most of what
we do we just want uniformly distributed numbers to mix things up a
bit. Any patterns in the generated sequence probably aren't
particularly detrimental IMHO. Interested to know if others agree or
not.

Colin
